Defensive.description:
Defensive Ivysaur is an excellent utility Pokemon in the NFE tier thanks to its helpful typing and solid bulk. With Knock Off to remove Eviolite, Ivysaur can make foes like Dunsparce and Koffing much easier to handle for teammates that struggle against them, like Piloswine and Monferno. Sludge Bomb is a great STAB attack as it can allow Ivysaur to land poisons against defensive staples like Dunsparce and Hattrem, wearing them down quickly. Ivysaur is a superb wall against foes like Gabite, Thwackey, and Servine.

Ivysaur is a great choice for balance and bulky offense teams that want a grounded Poison-type to absorb Toxic Spikes while offering tremendous utility in the form of Knock Off support. Teammates that can appreciate the Eviolite and Toxic Spikes removal include setup sweepers like Girafarig, Monferno, and Dunsparce, helping blow past foes like Tinkatuff and Drakloak; wallbreakers like Pignite and Thwackey also benefit greatly, breaking through walls like Koffing and Dunsparce much easier. Stealth Rock setters like Piloswine and Tinkatuff have great defensive synergy with Ivysaur and are valuable to help wear down the opposition with entry hazard chip damage, as well as, in Tinkatuff's case, helping spread status with Thunder Wave to enable the aforementioned offensive threats even further. Quaxwell is a great teammate, helping sponge attacks from Fire-types like Pignite and Raboot while offering hazard removal to help Ivysaur not get worn down as quickly. Ivysaur, despite its Poison-typing, has a hard time breaking past Koffing because of its combination of Will-O-Wisp and Sludge Bomb; partners like Drakloak and Hisuian Sliggoo are important to help keep Koffing in check. Girafarig and Piloswine are notable threats to Ivysaur, making teammates like Quaxwell and Tinkatuff even more valuable.

Shell Smash.description:
Shell Smash Wartortle is an effective setup sweeper in the NFE metagame. Hydro Pump can be used over Surf to more reliably break through foes like specially defensive Tinkatuff, with favorable odds to 2HKO it after taking Spikes chip damage. Ice Beam helps nail Dragon- and Grass-types like Drakloak, Gabite, Ivysaur, and Servine. Substitute can provide a safe opportunity to avoid status and set up against foes that will be forced to switch out, such as Koffing and Piloswine; Rapid Spin is an alternative that can help with boosting Wartortle's Speed while also allowing it to function as entry hazard removal for its team. The Speed investment ensures that Wartortle can outspeed Drakloak, Frogadier, and Raboot at +2 while also outpacing the niche Hakamo-o and Mienfoo at +1.

Wartortle is a powerful setup sweeper for bulky offense and offense teams, though it struggles to break through metagame staples like Quaxwell and Tinkatuff without adequate support. Such support can come in the form of entry hazard setters like Frogadier, Piloswine, and Tinkatuff. Drakloak and Dusclops are valuable teammatesas they provide spinblock support against Quaxwell as well as disruption in the form of status spreading to help Wartortle set up more effectively. Knock Off partners like Clefairy and Monferno are valuable, as they can offer Eviolite removal to help a boosted Wartortle secure KOs against foes like Coil Dunsparce and Quaxwell after some chip damage, as well as offer Stealth Rock support. Offensive setup partners, like Swords Dance users Gabite and Thwackey and Nasty Plot Girafarig, can provide tremendous support in wearing down foes that Wartortle struggles against, like Dunsparce and Hisuian Sliggoo. Toxic Spikes support from Glimmet, Ivysaur, and Koffing can also help break through Dunsparce and Quaxwell, though Wartortle still needs them chipped down considerably before attempting to set up and sweep. Thwackey is a great partner, as it provides Grassy Terrain to help Wartortle recover health, allowing it some more leeway while setting up. Servine is a notable Wartortle counter, threatening to OHKO it with Leaf Storm; Monferno and Raboot are great partners to sponge attacks from Servine while offering offensive support and safe entry points via U-turn.

Clefairy.overview: Despite its appearance and seemingly low stats, Clefairy is a deceptively sturdy wall in the NFE metagame, using its access to several great utility moves like Knock Off, Stealth Rock, and Thunder Wave to much success. Capable of running either physically or specially defensive sets, Clefairy is flexible in supporting its teammates, such as using Stealth Rock to allow partners like Gabite and Piloswine to focus more on their offensive capabilities. Magic Guard is a useful tool that allows Clefairy to avoid taking residual entry hazard chip damage while sponging status for its teammates without taking residual damage. While Clefairy does offer immense upside as a utility machine, it does compete for the role with Tinkatuff, a dominant figure in the tier. While Tinkatuff is generally better than Clefairy because of its Steel typing, it does not have access to recovery, which makes Clefairy a capable choice for teams that want their Knock Off and Thunder Wave user to stick around.
Clefairy.comments:
Other Options

Clefairy has access to Calm Mind, which can be used with attacks like Draining Kiss and Flamethrower to hit a large swath of the metagame for nice damage after a few boosts. Healing Wish can allow powerful wallbreakers like Girafarig and Piloswine a second chance to break through the opposition. Trick can be used to disrupt foes as well, opting to steal Eviolite from the foe rather than using Knock Off to remove it or using an unfavorable item like a Choice Scarf to disrupt a switch-in such as Koffing or Tinkatuff.

Checks and Counters

Item Disruption: Clefairy can struggle to function as a wall once its Eviolite is removed, rendering it less effective against Knock Off users like Monferno, Servine, and Thwackey. Switcheroo and Trick users, such as Frogadier and Girafarig, can also disrupt Clefairy by giving it an unsavory Choice item.

Poison-types: Koffing, because of its ability Neutralizing Gas removing the effect of Magic Guard, can threaten Clefairy out and use Toxic Spikes to disrupt. Alolan Grimer and Ivysaur can threaten big damage against Clefairy with their STAB attacks while also using Knock Off to remove Eviolite from whatever switches into them.

Steel-types: Hisuian Sliggoo can use its powerful Steel-type STAB attacks to obliterate Clefairy, while Tinkatuff can wall non-Night Shade Clefairy with ease and disrupt it with Encore and Knock Off. Pawniard can use Clefairy as a relatively safe entry point, setting up with Swords Dance or threatening big damage with Iron Head immediately.

Defensive.description:
Clefairy offers incredible utility, giving teams a sturdy Knock Off user that can also establish Stealth Rock and disrupt foes with Thunder Wave, all valuable tools that help against the premier entry hazard removal option in the tier, Quaxwell. Encore can similarly disrupt the opponent, though it is prediction-reliant, as most things will be faster than Clefairy without being paralyzed. Night Shade can be used to provide consistent damage output, though it can't hit Dunsparce and Girafarig, giving them opportunities to set up in front of Clefairy. Magic Guard allows Clefairy to sponge status moves and other forms of residual damage for its teammates, such as Toxic from Dunsparce, Salt Cure from Naclstack, and Will-O-Wisp from Drakloak, though it does still suffer the effects of paralysis and takes boosted damage from Hex while statused. A specially defensive EV spread with a Calm nature lets Clefairy focus on checking Pokemon like Drakloak, Frogadier, and Choice Specs Drakloak, while a physically defensive EV spread with a Bold nature can let it check Monferno and Piloswine.

A natural fit on balance and bulky offense teams, Clefairy can use its utility to free up a moveslot on teammates like Dunsparce, Gabite, and Piloswine. Clefairy uses its bulk and general longevity to disrupt the opposition drastically, allowing offensive teammates, like Frogadier and Girafarig, to clean late-game after Eviolites are removed from walls such as Dunsparce and Tinkatuff. Frogadier is a notable partner for Clefairy, as it uses Spikes to create an entry hazard-stacking core that, with Drakloak as a spinblocker, can rack up hazard chip damage. While Clefairy is fairly bulky and can use Moonlight to stick around for longer, it is generally frail once its Eviolite is removed and can struggle to wall the stronger setup sweepers and wallbreakers in the tier, such as Nasty Plot Girafarig, Contrary + Leaf Storm Servine, and Swords Dance Thwackey. To help with this, Hisuian Sliggoo can cover a lot of these threats because of its own bulk and Steel typing, and it can capitalize on Clefairy removing Eviolites on foes to maximize the damage output of its own strong STAB attacks like Draco Meteor and Flash Cannon. Koffing and Pawniard can also help sponge Knock Offs for Clefairy, with Koffing providing great offensive pressure with Toxic Spikes and Pawniard being a reliable wallbreaker. Fighting-types like Pignite can help Clefairy break through the bulkier Normal- and Steel-types that it can struggle against, like Dunsparce and Hisuian Sliggoo. Gabite can similarly help break through these Pokemon while also threatening Koffing and other Poison-types like Glimmet.

Koffing.comments:
Other Options

While Levitate allow Koffing to wall offensive Ground-types like Gabite, it comes at the cost of Koffing's critically important ability to absorb opposing Toxic Spikes as a grounded Poison-type and various interactions that Neutralizing Gas makes favorable. Toxic is great at making progress and preferable against Dunsparce and special attackers, but it renders Koffing even more passive against Steel-types.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Tinkatuff and Hisuian Sliggoo both wall Koffing and are not immediately deterred by Will-O-Wisp, freely able to set Stealth Rock or start wallbreaking.

Psychic-types: Girafarig and Duosion are both extremely immediately threatening to Koffing and can potentially sweep if given free turns to set up. Duosion is particularly fearsome as it is unaffected by the passive damage from Toxic Spikes due to Magic Guard once Koffing is forced out. RestTalk Hattrem is comfortable switching into Koffing and healing off status damage while threatening to use its STAB moves or Nuzzle.

Ghost-types: Dusclops and Drakloak commonly run Night Shade, which lets them trade health against Koffing very efficiently due to its low HP stat. While rare, Lampent is also a nightmare to deal with thanks to its strong special attacks and Flash Fire turning Will-O-Wisp into a beneficial effect.

Special Wallbreakers: Light Ball-boosted Pikachu and Choice Specs users like Frogadier, Drakloak, and Hisuian Sliggoo all threaten enormous damage on Koffing and are difficult for its teammates to switch into.

Defensive.description:
Thanks to its typing and exceptional physical bulk, Koffing is a great defensive glue and the premier Toxic Spikes setter of the metagame. Sludge Bomb is Koffing's best STAB option and its high chance to poison can punish common switch-ins like Girafarig and Drakloak. Will-O-Wisp prevents attackers like Pawniard and Coil Dunsparce from setting up on Koffing and puts Steel-types like Tinkatuff and Hisuian Sliggoo on a timer. Toxic Spikes creates extreme pressure against most team structures due to the limited usage Heavy-Duty Boots sees. Thief turns Koffing into a Knock Off absorber and allows it to steal back Eviolite. Flamethrower gives a more direct way to punish Steel-type switch-ins. Neutralizing Gas allows Koffing to bypass Magic Guard and Magic Bounce from Clefairy and Hattrem respectively, use Thief on Tinkatuff without Pickpocket activating, and induce status effects on Naclstack.

Koffing fits best on slower balance or stall archetypes that create longer games, need more long-term answers to threats like Thwackey, and get more value from Toxic Spikes's incremental damage. A Ghost-type partner such as Dusclops or Drakloak is essential to block spinners like Quaxwell and Wartortle. Steel-types like Tinkatuff and Hisuian Sliggoo can halt special wallbreakers like Girafarig and Frogadier that pose big threats once let in. Koffing's best defensive trait is that it walls common Grass-types like Servine, Ivysaur, and especially Thwackey. Therefore, wallbreakers that can make immediate progress but let those in for free like Piloswine, Wartortle, and Drakloak are all most appreciative of its defensive utility. Lastly, bulkier wincons like Duosion and Dunsparce really appreciate Toxic Spikes's passive damage as it eases setup for them and makes them even harder to keep checked.

Girafarig.comments:
Other Options

While weaker than Psychic, Psychic Noise can punish Clefairy and Dunsparce for switching in by preventing them from healing accumulated chip damage. Psyshock is an option against opposing Calm Mind users such as Dunsparce and is the strongest available move against Hisuian Sliggoo. On the Choice Specs set, Future Sight is a notable option to brute force progress.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Tinkatuff, Hisuian Sliggoo, and Pawniard all resist Girafarig's STAB options and can threaten it with status, powerful attacks, or their own setup.

Fast Revenge Killers: Naturally fast Pokemon like Raboot, Drakloak, and Pikachu and Choice Scarf users like Frogadier and Monferno can force out Girafarig with the threat of powerful attacks or disruptive moves like Switcheroo.

Thunder Wave Users: Drakloak and Tinkatuff can neuter Girafarig with paralysis and allow slower threats like Pignite and Piloswine to trade favorably against it, though Drakloak hates switching in against Girafarig.

Encore Users: Passive Pokemon such as a Tinkatuff and Quaxwell can still prevent a sweep by locking Girafarig into Nasty Plot or an attack that is easier to pivot around.

Choice Specs.description:
Choice Specs Girafarig is one of the scariest wallbreakers in the tier, blasting through offensive and defensive foes with its narrowly-resisted STAB combination and good Speed. Hyper Voice targets Psychic-resistant Pokemon like Duosion, opposing Girafarig, and Alolan Grimer. Trick cripples anticipated switch-ins like Tinkatuff and Clefairy. After trading away or losing its Choice Specs, Nasty Plot can let Girafarig set up against walls like Quaxwell and Clefairy. Thunderbolt is its strongest option against select targets like Quaxwell, Pawniard, and Vullaby. Sap Sipper gives Girafarig additional switch-in opportunities against Grass-types like Servine, Thwackey, and Ivysaur, though it should be wary of their utility moves like Knock Off, or in Servine's case, Glare.

Girafarig greatly benefits from pivots like Thwackey and Quaxwell, with the former providing Knock Off support and passive recovery and the latter providing entry hazard removal. Fire-types like Monferno and Raboot can threaten out Steel-types like Tinkatuff and Hisuian Sliggoo, two otherwise common switch-ins, while also providing pivoting support. Entry hazard support from setters like Piloswine and Tinkatuff can help push foes into range of Girafarig's moves, such as consistently allowing it to 2HKO Piloswine and OHKO opposing Girafarig with the right attack. Piloswine is a notable teammate that performs well against Tinkatuff and Clefairy and can absorb Thunder Wave while providing additional entry hazard support. Offensive Water-types like Wartortle and Choice Scarf Frogadier can capitalize on Girafarig's wallbreaking and help finish off the opposition; they also appreciate having a switch-in to Grass-types. Dragon-types like Fraxure and Gabite can work together to overwhelm shared checks such as Clefairy and Tinkatuff with their powerful STAB attacks. Status spreaders like Servine and Hattrem pair well to slow down the opposition with paralysis. Knock Off absorbers and disruptors like Koffing allow Girafarig to maintain its wallbreaking prowess.

Nasty Plot.description:
Girafarig is a premier setup threat thanks to its strong offensive typing and blistering Speed, only being immediately threatened offensively by Frogadier, Raboot, and faster Choice Scarf users. Its solid bulk and immunity to Ghost- and Grass-type attacks via Sap Sipper give it plenty of opportunities to set up and unleash Nasty Plot-boosted attacks. Hyper Voice and Psychic hit nearly the entire tier for neutral damage. Thunderbolt is Girafarig's strongest move to hit Steel-types such as Tinkatuff and Pawniard, very easily becoming overwhelming with Knock Off and entry hazard support. Substitute allows Girafarig to take advantage of passive Pokemon such as Quaxwell and Dunsparce while also potentially preventing status from Drakloak.

Girafarig can flexibly fit into faster and slower team archetypes and requires minimal specialized support. Thwackey and Ivysaur make excellent partners, as they force in shared checks to Girafarig such as Tinkatuff and Hisuian Sliggoo and punish them with Knock Off; the latter can also pivot Girafarig into setup opportunities with U-turn while the former acts as an important secondary defensive check to Thwackey, which can still cripple Girafarig with Knock Off. Tinkatuff is another exceptional teammate, as it compresses a user of Stealth Rock, Knock Off for opposing Steel-types, and Thunder Wave for nuisances to Girafarig like Frogadier and Drakloak into one teamslot. Dedicated Knock Off absorbers such as Thief Koffing and Pawniard are appreciated as ways to take advantage of an otherwise very hard to punish move. Lastly, Mareanie is worth a mention, as despite its passivity, it has a very comfortable time checking revenge killers like Monferno, Pawniard, and Raboot and can soft check Hisuian Sliggoo, which all are sizable offensive threats when they come in on Girafarig.

Dunsparce.overview: Dunsparce is one of NFE's sturdiest walls and wincons, boasting a wide array of utility moves and coverage. Serene Grace-enhanced attacks discourage incoming Normal-resistant foes like Drakloak and Tinkatuff from freely setting up on it. Dunsparce's bulk enables it to set up on staples like Piloswine and Gabite, and each of its setup sets are effective in their own right: Coil sets outlast physical attackers like Piloswine and Fraxure, while Calm Mind sets can frustrate special attackers like Frogadier and Duosion. Alternatively, Dunsparce can be an excellent Stealth Rock setter by using its defensive prowess and movepool. However, Dunsparce can be quite passive without boosts and is very vulnerable to residual damage; status and entry hazards compromise its walling capabilities and make it much easier to check. Walls like Tinkatuff and Quaxwell can take advantage of its low offensive prowess with Encore to lock it into exploitable moves.
Dunsparce.comments:
Other Options

Rattled can be used on any of Dunsparce's sets to more easily take on Knock Off and U-turn users like Vullaby and Thwackey, though losing Serene Grace makes it easier for checks to switch into it. Toxic is plausible for breaking down bulky threats like Quaxwell and Quilladin, though Poison-types and Poison-immune threats are commonplace in the metagame, not to mention it being difficult to give up a coverage choice like Bite, Earth Power, or Ice Beam.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types and Fighting-type coverage: Barring boosts and unlucky paralysis rolls, common Fighting-types like Monferno and Pignite are some of Dunsparce's worst matchups, taking most of its attacks with ease and retaliating with Knock Off or powerful STAB moves. While Hakamo-o is more niche, it can use defensive sets to heal paralysis and phaze Dunsparce with Dragon Tail, or it can outlast Dunsparce in the setup war with offensive sets. While not a Fighting-type itself, Raboot can use Libero-boosted coverage and remain similarly threatening.

Steel-types: While they dislike paralysis, Steel-types like Tinkatuff and Hisuian Sliggoo can wear Dunsparce down with their utility moves: the former's access to Thunder Wave and Encore disrupts sweeping attempts, while the latter's Acid Spray weakens Dunsparce's special bulk and makes it much easier to defeat. Pawniard can set up on utility and Coil sets but falters against Calm Mind variants.

Residual Damage: Being quite passive without boosts and being weak to all entry hazards, Dunsparce's walling capabilities falter if it is afflicted with any status. Pokemon that can inflict poison and burn like Ivysaur and Koffing force it to use Roost more often for longevity, while paralysis spreaders like Tinkatuff and Hattrem frustrates its sweeping capabilities.

Item Disruption: Dunsparce's defensive prowess becomes much worse without its Eviolite, so Knock Off users like Tinkatuff, Thwackey, and Ivysaur can force it out early-game. Trick or Switcheroo users like Girafarig, Frogadier, and Lampent can give Dunsparce Choice items that can make it even easier to wall.

Naclstack: While relatively uncommon, Naclstack is immune to status conditions and can whittle Dunsparce down with Salt Cure or even use it as setup fodder with IronPress sets.

Ghost-types: Dusclops can easily tank any of Dunsparce's attacks and remove potential boosts with Haze, only fearing the rare Toxic. However, Dusclops is unable to damage Dunsparce back aside from Will-O-Wisp and Pain Split. Despite Lampent's frailty, it can completely wall Dunsparce's utility sets if certain coverage is not elected.

Calm Mind.description:
Thanks to Dunsparce's immense bulk, it can set up against a majority of physical attackers and passive walls, examples that include Piloswine, Gabite, Hattrem, and Quilladin. After a Calm Mind boost, Dunsparce can more easily take on Choice Specs threats like Frogadier and Girafarig. Ice Beam threatens Grass-types like Ivysaur, Servine, and Thwackey. Earth Power can be used to more easily take on Steel-types like Tinkatuff and Hisuian Sliggoo as well as Naclstack, though Thunderbolt hits Water-types like Wartortle and Quaxwell.

Dunsparce tends to fit best on bulky and balanced teams that are looking to compress a wincon and physical wall into one slot. Even with Earth Power, Steel-types like Tinkatuff and Hisuian Sliggoo can take Dunsparce on well and wear it down with utility and Acid Spray, respectively. Walls like Clefairy and Quaxwell are difficult to take down even with boosts, so wallbreakers like Choice Specs Girafarig and Thwackey can deal with them. Fighting-types like Monferno and Pignite threaten Dunsparce with their STAB moves, so checks to them like Koffing, Quaxwell, and Gabite are appreciated. Knock Off users like Clefairy and Thwackey can jeopardize Dunsparce's sweeping attempts, so Knock Off absorbers like Koffing and Tinkatuff are helpful to preserve its bulk. Dunsparce is especially vulnerable to entry hazards, so hazard removers like Fletchinder and Quaxwell are helpful to prevent it from being worn down by residual damage. Wallbreakers like Fraxure and Pignite can facilitate Dunsparce's sweeping attempts late-game by breaking down Steel-types and opposing walls.

Utility.description:
Dunsparce offers tremendous upsides as a bulky Stealth Rock setter and paralysis spreader. Headbutt is a potent STAB attack when used in conjunction with Serene Grace, allowing Dunsparce to utilize paraflinch strategies to great effect. Body Slam is an option to provide great value in the form of boosted paralysis spreading. Glare enables these paraflinch maneuvers even further by being able to paralyze Ground- and Ghost-types like Gabite, Piloswine, and Drakloak; Ice Beam is an alternative that allows Dunsparce to hit foes like Drakloak and Dusclops while fishing for freeze as well. With full bulk investment on the special side, Dunsparce can reliably wall common foes like Frogadier and Wartortle.

As a Stealth Rock setter with reliable recovery and great support moves in Glare and Serene Grace-boosted Body Slam, Dunsparce fits best on balance and bulky offense teams with teammates that can use the disruption to their benefit, like Swords Dance + Substitute Gabite and Shell Smash Wartortle. Other teammates that benefit from Dunsparce's paralysis include Drakloak, as it bolsters their damage output tremendously against would-be checks like Tinkatuff. Dunsparce pairs well with Pokemon that can help stack entry hazards, like Frogadier and Koffing, which offer Spikes and Toxic Spikes support, respectively. Since Dunsparce occupies the Stealth Rock setter role, teammates like Gabite and Piloswine can use more offensively oriented sets to wallbreak more effectively. Quaxwell is a notable partner that can provide valuable hazard removal to prevent Dunsparce from being worn down, and Ivysaur can help Dunsparce with item removal and absorbing Toxic Spikes. Dunsparce is weak to a plethora of physical attacking foes like Monferno, Pignite, and Raboot, so Koffing and Quaxwell are much appreciated as switch-ins to them. Knock Off absorbers, like the aforementioned Monferno and Pignite, are also appreciated immensely, as they can help Dunsparce preserve its Eviolite to better spread status and disrupt foes throughout a game.

Coil.description:
Coil Dunsparce is an effective setup sweeper that leverages its natural bulk to rack up boosts against common foes like Frogadier and Clefairy. Headbutt is the STAB attack of choice because of the boosted flinch rate provided by Serene Grace. Bite allows Dunsparce to hit Ghost-types and also benefits from Serene Grace; Glare is an alternative that allows Dunsparce to set up its own paraflinch opportunities and can disrupt switch-ins like Monferno and Pignite, though it misses out on being able to hit common foes like Drakloak and Dusclops. Dunsparce invests in Special Defense since it racks up Defense boosts with Coil, and the Speed investment ensures it outpaces foes like Hattrem, as well as paralyzed Piloswine and Tinkatuff.

An effective late-game setup sweeper, Coil Dunsparce fits well on bulky offense teams that can enable it by spreading paralysis via Pokemon like Drakloak and Tinkatuff. Other paralysis spreaders like Clefairy and Hattrem are valuable, as they can also help with entry hazard control; Hattrem offers Healing Wish support in the event Dunsparce gets afflicted with a status as well. Other offensive teammates that can leverage the paralysis spread include Drakloak and Pignite; Drakloak uses boosted Hex to break past walls like Tinkatuff more effectively, while Pignite can use the Speed drop from paralysis to break past faster foes like Girafarig and Drakloak. Quaxwell is a valuable teammate to keep hazards removed, preventing Glare Dunsparce from getting worn down while it spreads paralysis. Gabite and Koffing offer valuable switch-ins against Fighting-type foes like Monferno and Pignite, with the latter absorbing Toxic Spikes as well, which keeps Dunsparce healthy for a late-game sweep potentially. Dunsparce does not like to get statused, making teammates like Clefairy, Monferno, and Pignite great options to absorb burn attempts from Pokemon like Dusclops and disrupt foes with Knock Off. Offensive Stealth Rock setters like Gabite, Monferno, and Piloswine are valuable, since Coil Dunsparce doesn't fulfill the hazard setter role and appreciates shared checks like Quaxwell being pressured. Drakloak can help against Quaxwell as well, acting as a secondary paralysis spreader and spinblocker. Non-Bite Dunsparce sets can't hit Ghost-types like Drakloak and Lampent, so teammates that can help take them on, such as Girafarig and Hisuian Sliggoo, are important.

Piloswine.overview: With its impressive stats, versatile movepool, good typing, and notable ability, Piloswine cements itself as one of the premier staples of the metagame. All these traits allow it to function as an excellent wallbreaker, entry hazard setter, revenge killer, and Thunder Wave absorber. As a hazard setter, being unsusceptible to Taunt owing to its ability is a major plus point. While Eviolite provides bulk and flexibility, Choice Band enables Piloswine to capitalize on its unresisted STAB combination to dismantle opposing teams. However, despite its strength and bulk, it lacks longevity due to the absence of non-Rest recovery moves and faces competition from other Stealth Rock setters like Tinkatuff and Dunsparce, which have relatively better longevity, better matchup against the tier's premier hazard removal option in Quaxwell, and greater overall utility.
Piloswine.comments:
Other Options

Trailblaze over Ice Shard or Stealth Rock with more Speed EVs is an option for Piloswine. For instance, it outspeeds Frogadier at +2 with 104 Speed EVs. Trailblaze transforms Piloswine into a good late-game cleaner, potentially bypassing checks like Thwackey at low HP and picking off foes like Monferno. This alternative also helps it in winning mirror matchups. However, if one drops Stealth Rock, it's advisable to run another setter like Tinkatuff, or if one drops Ice Shard, consider other revenge killers like Thwackey and Choice Scarf Frogadier. Similarly, Curse is an option over Stealth Rock, making Piloswine a dangerous late-game cleaner and enabling it to beat its former checks such as Thwackey and Raboot.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Quaxwell can switch into any move from Piloswine and use Rapid Spin to remove Stealth Rock. It can do so multiple times thanks to Roost and threatens Piloswine out with its STAB moves. Other Water-types like Wartortle and Frogadier can check Piloswine with their STAB attacks too. Wartortle also has Rapid Spin to remove Stealth Rock and is bulky enough to switch into Piloswine once or twice; Frogadier is relatively frailer but stronger.

Wallbreakers and Revenge Killers: Thwackey can check Piloswine, but it usually needs support to get Piloswine weakened to Grassy Glide range, generally with Knock Off, strong super effective moves, or pivoting moves, as it would rather not risk Wood Hammer. Raboot, Monferno, and Pignite heavily damage Piloswine with their Fighting-type moves. Pokemon such as Choice Specs Girafarig, Servine, and Pawniard do a decent job in picking Piloswine off.

Dunsparce: Dunsparce is physically bulky enough to easily take all of Piloswine's STAB moves with impunity. Dunsparce cripples Piloswine with Toxic and can recover the damage off with Roost.

Offensive Stealth Rock.description:
Piloswine's strong matchups against the tier's other dominant entry hazard setters, such as Tinkatuff and Koffing, and the tier's premier Defogger, Vullaby, allow it to excel as a highly effective Stealth Rock setter. As a wallbreaker, its unresisted STAB combination is extremely threatening to unprepared teams and those that have been weakened by Knock Off, hazards, or other residual damage. High Horsepower allows Piloswine to work effectively even in Grassy Terrain, but Earthquake is also a viable alternative due to its extra power and accuracy. Ice Shard allows Piloswine to pick off weakened threats like Girafarig and Fraxure.

Piloswine is a strong fit for most archetypes, and it's especially effective on bulky offense and balance teams. Drakloak is a good teammate for Piloswine; its spinblocking ability, which allows it to handle Quaxwell, complements Piloswine's Stealth Rock setting perfectly. In addition, Drakloak can spread status to support Piloswine's wallbreaking or work in tandem with it to dismantle the opposing team through pivoting. Frogadier is also a superb partner, forming an entry hazard-stacking core with Piloswine; moreover, it provides pivoting support to Piloswine, creating valuable entry opportunities. In a similar vein, Koffing sets Toxic Spikes to maximize hazard pressure; it also acts as a great switch-in to many foes that Piloswine is weak to, handling Grass-types like Thwackey and Servine and absorbing Fighting-type moves from threats like Raboot, Monferno, and Pignite. In general, wallbreakers and cleaners appreciate Piloswine's Stealth Rock support and offensive pressure; Thwackey, Girafarig, Fraxure, and Raboot synergize extremely well with Piloswine, working hand in hand with it to dismantle defensive cores, which may include Pokemon like Dunsparce, Ivysaur, Quaxwell, and Koffing. Thwackey, in particular, is an excellent teammate for Piloswine, dealing with pesky Water-types that check Piloswine, namely Quaxwell, Wartortle, and Frogadier. Thwackey also offers invaluable Knock Off, pivoting, and passive recovery support, bolstering Piloswine's wallbreaking prowess and longevity. In return, Piloswine deals with foes that can prove to be problematic for Thwackey, such as Koffing, Vullaby, and Tinkatuff. Piloswine appreciates Knock Off support a ton; thus, Knock Off users such as Monferno, Pignite, and Ivysaur make amazing teammates, pairing nicely with Piloswine and amplifying its offensive pressure, even allowing it to reach thresholds like 2HKOing maximum Defense Quaxwell that has lost its Eviolite with minimum chip damage. Defensively, Quaxwell is a remarkable teammate, providing Rapid Spin support to ensure Piloswine's side of the field is free of hazards, thus maximizing hazard pressure on the opposing team. Quaxwell also acts as a switch-in to multiple Pokemon that Piloswine can struggle against, especially if it's chipped or if its Eviolite has been removed by Knock Off, such as Frogadier, Pignite, Monferno, and Raboot; in exchange, Piloswine can deal with foes that Quaxwell is weak to, like Drakloak, Fraxure, and Girafarig. Wartortle is also a good teammate in this regard, though it has less longevity, which is a fair trade for the added offensive pressure. Ivysaur defensively takes care of Grass- and Water-types like Thwackey and Quaxwell for Piloswine, while Piloswine takes care of threats like Girafarig and Tinkatuff.

Choice Band.description:
Thanks to its insane Attack and amazing movepool, Choice Band Piloswine is one of the deadliest wallbreakers and revenge killers of the metagame. High Horsepower is the preferred move under Thwackey's Grassy Terrain, while Earthquake serves as a more consistent option outside of it. Ice Shard picks off foes like Fraxure, Gabite, and low-HP Girafarig. 124 Speed EVs ensure Piloswine outspeeds Quaxwell without Speed investment. Maximum Attack and Speed investment can also be used to not risk Speed tier shenanigans.

Piloswine fits on bulky offense and balance teams. It is best paired with entry hazard setters like Tinkatuff, Frogadier, and Koffing to relentlessly pressure foes like Quaxwell and wallbreak as effectively as possible. Tinkatuff and Koffing also act as Knock Off absorbers, aiding Piloswine in keeping its Choice Band, and they also check Grass-types like Thwackey, Ivysaur, and Servine. Tinkatuff can also try to steal Quaxwell's Eviolite with Pickpocket, invalidating it as a potential Piloswine answer. Monferno and Pignite provide Knock Off support and offensively pressure Quaxwell structures Piloswine may face some difficulty against. Special stallbreakers and wallbreakers such as Servine and Choice Specs Girafarig can work in tandem with Piloswine to dismantle opposing defensive cores with Pokemon like Quaxwell, Dunsparce, Ivysaur, and Tinkatuff. Thwackey and Ivysaur check pesky Water-types that check Piloswine, namely Frogadier, Wartortle, and Quaxwell, while also providing Knock Off support and, in Thwackey's case, passive recovery. In return, Piloswine handles Tinkatuff and Vullaby for them. Piloswine likes taking as little chip damage as possible, so hazard control options such as Quaxwell, Wartortle, and Vullaby are appreciated. Fraxure can take advantage of the holes Piloswine blows into opposing teams to set up and sweep. Servine is also an excellent partner for similar reasons and aids Piloswine by checking Water-types and providing Glare support, potentially mitigating its issue of having mediocre Speed. Pikachu also checks Water-types and provides Volt Switch support to Piloswine, bringing it in on forced switches and enabling its wallbreaking.

Monferno.overview: Monferno is one of the best Fire-types in the tier and the most versatile of them. Monferno's Speed, power, and coverage make it an excellent Swords Dance sweeper that can overrun teams without sturdy Fire- and Fighting-type checks, backed up with options like Knock Off and Mach Punch. Monferno can also tap into its utility more to become an all-out attacker, becoming an elite pivot with U-turn while still having STAB moves, Knock Off, and good Speed to back it up. Lastly, its Nasty Plot sets are fantastic at luring physical walls anticipating its physical sets. Monferno's set versatility culminates it in being both a great revenge killer and cleaner. Monferno, however, struggles against physical walls and Water-types like Koffing, Gabite, and Quaxwell without a moderate amount of team support. While Monferno's Speed tier is good, it is still vulnerable to getting outpaced by faster foes like Girafarig and Frogadier. Lastly, Monferno faces competition from its Fire-type brethren, as it has neither Raboot's higher Speed and more diverse coverage nor Pignite's Ground-type coverage and raw strength.
Monferno.comments:
Other Options

Slack Off can be run on any of Monferno's sets to provide longevity, though they lose out on important utility in Knock Off or U-turn by doing so. A Choice Scarf set outspeeds the entire unboosted metagame, revenge killing faster foes like Girafarig, Raboot, and Frogadier; it can even use Switcheroo to cripple walls like Quaxwell and Koffing. However, this set loses out on Monferno's flexibility and the bulk gained from Eviolite. Thunder Punch can be used to deal with Mareanie and deal more damage to Quaxwell and Wartortle, though this move is hard to fit over a utility move like Knock Off or U-turn.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Quaxwell and Mareanie are Monferno's most sturdy checks, able to survive any attacks with ease and retaliate with their STAB moves or make progress against it with Rapid Spin and Toxic Spikes, respectively. Seadra's Poison Point can punish physical Monferno sets for making contact with poison. More offensive Water-types, like Wartortle and Frogadier, can similarly threaten Monferno out with their STAB attacks but have trouble switching in.

Revenge Killers: While Monferno has good Speed, it still falls short of many faster threats and is vulnerable to being OHKOed or taking significant damage from them before attacking. Examples of such threats include Girafarig, Drakloak, and Raboot.

Physical Walls: Defensive behemoths like Koffing and defensive Gabite can stomach at least one of Monferno's attacks before retaliating with their STAB moves; Gabite is particularly dangerous, with its STAB Earthquake and Rough Skin threatening to immediately end Monferno's sweep. Hattrem can threaten a KO after Monferno takes Stealth Rock damage, but it hates switching into Knock Off. Fletchinder resists both of Monferno's STAB moves and U-turn and can threaten it out with STAB Brave Bird, while Clefairy can threaten Thunder Wave and chip it down with Night Shade. Both walls also have a recovery move to heal off accumulated damage.

Swords Dance.description:
Monferno's Speed, power, utility, and typing enable it to be one of the scariest sweepers in the tier. Swords Dance boosts Monferno's Attack to threatening levels, enabling Close Combat to 2HKO Water-type checks like Quaxwell and Wartortle as well as letting Flare Blitz 2HKO Koffing and physically defensive Clefairy. Knock Off weakens checks like the aforementioned Quaxwell and Koffing while easing setup late-game; it also 2HKOes Drakloak after Stealth Rock. Mach Punch is an alternative to Knock Off that deals significant damage to faster revenge killers like Frogadier, Girafarig, and Raboot. Blaze is the preferred ability to further heighten Monferno's Flare Blitz at low HP, though Iron Fist can be used to boost Mach Punch's power.

Monferno fits as a fantastic cleaner on offensive teams or as an offensive Swiss Army knife in balanced builds. Water-types like Quaxwell and Mareanie can extinguish Monferno's sweep early with their excellent bulk; Grass-types like Thwackey, Servine, and Ivysaur are helpful to check these threats. Revenge killers like Girafarig, Gabite, and Choice Specs Drakloak can outspeed and pick it off without much chip damage; defensive backbones like Tinkatuff and utility Dunsparce can be helpful in soaking up damage while accumulating progress with Stealth Rock and paralysis. Knock Off users like Ivysaur and Vullaby are immensely helpful for wearing down walls like Gabite and Koffing, enabling Monferno to sweep much more easily. Other wallbreakers and cleaners, like Fraxure, Thwackey, and Girafarig, can take advantage of Monferno's wallbreaking or help it clean themselves; Thwackey also provides useful healing and reduces Earthquake's damage with Grassy Terrain.

All-out Attacker.description:
Monferno is an offensively versatile attacker with Knock Off, pivoting, and generally solid dual STAB attacks against common Pokemon in the tier, such as Thwackey, Tinkatuff, Piloswine, and Dunsparce. Its Fire typing makes it a suitable wallbreaker due to it not being crippled by Will-O-Wisp from notable Pokemon like Dusclops and Koffing. U-turn lets Monferno pivot out on its unfavorable matchups and bring its teammates into favorable matchups. Knock Off is especially potent in NFE due to Eviolite being the item on walls such as Gabite, Quaxwell, and Drakloak that could normally give Monferno and its teammates a hard time.

Monferno fits best onto balance and offensive teams that appreciate a switch-in to Thwackey, a Knock Off user that invites in Quaxwell, or a pivot to help establish a pivot core. Monferno appreciates teammates such as Girafarig and Thwackey to threaten its main checks in Koffing, Mareanie, and Quaxwell. It also pairs well with teammates like Tinkatuff and Frogadier, which can set entry hazards and weaken foes. Tinkatuff is especially helpful by spreading paralysis to allow Monferno to outspeed and pivot out on potentially dangerous foes, such as Frogadier, Girafarig, and Drakloak. Monferno supports wallbreakers and sweepers like Fraxure and Piloswine by luring in bulky walls like Quaxwell and using Knock Off to weaken them, making it easier for teammates to break through them later. Additionally, it aids these teammates by being a good switch-in to Pokemon like Tinkatuff and Thwackey. Monferno benefits from teammates like Clefairy, Quaxwell, and Koffing, which can absorb the otherwise dangerous Water- and Ground-type attacks it could receive from foes, such as Piloswine, Gabite, and Quaxwell.

Nasty Plot.description:
Monferno is a surprising special setup sweeper, as it’s more commonly expected to be physical. It can lure in physical walls like Gabite or physically defensive Clefairy. Once it has set up, Monferno becomes a potent late-game cleaner, using its powerful, mostly unresisted STAB moves to threaten the opposition. Focus Blast provides essential coverage, dealing with foes like Hisuian Sliggoo, Piloswine, and Quaxwell. Vacuum Wave can pick up KOs on damaged faster foes like Girafarig or Frogadier. Timid nature ensures that Monferno outspeeds and OHKOs foes like Thwackey and allows it to deal sufficient damage without the need for the extra power that Modest would provide.

Monferno fits well on offensive teams thanks to its ability to clean up weakened foes late-game. It also excels on balance teams, where it supports physically offensive teammates like Thwackey and Piloswine by luring and removing physical walls such as Quaxwell and Koffing that would otherwise hinder their progress. Monferno pairs well with hazard setters like Tinkatuff, Frogadier, and Gabite, which can lay down Stealth Rock and Spikes to weaken the opponent, facilitating Monferno’s sweeps. A layer of Stealth Rock or Spikes enables Monferno, once boosted, to secure the OHKO range on bulkier foes such as defensive Tinkatuff with Fire Blast, or Coil Dunsparce and defensive Gabite with Focus Blast. Wallbreakers like Piloswine and Thwackey are essential teammates, as they clear out key defensive checks such as Mareanie and Quaxwell, respectively. Paralysis absorbers, such as Eelektrik and Piloswine, help mitigate Monferno’s vulnerability to paralysis, which could otherwise allow slower threats like Pignite or Piloswine to outspeed and threaten it. Thunder Wave spreaders are also valuable to provide additional speed control; teammates like Clefairy or Tinkatuff stop faster Pokemon, such as Murkrow or Frogadier, otherwise able to get the jump on Monferno. Grass-types like Servine or Thwackey are helpful dealing with the likes of Quaxwell or Gabite while resisting both Water- and Ground-type moves. Knock Off users like Vullaby or Thwackey are valuable additions to the team, as they ease Monferno's need for setting up.

Gabite.overview: Gabite uses its powerful Dragon and Ground typing in conjunction with Swords Dance to become a potentially devastating setup sweeper in the NFE metagame. Sitting at a comfortable speed tier ahead of other offensive threats like Monferno and Thwackey, Gabite is a solid choice for teams that need a powerful wallbreaker and setup option. On top of this, Gabite can establish Stealth Rock for its team and use its Ground typing to absorb paralysis attempts from the likes of Hattrem and Tinkatuff. While these traits are quite tantalizing, Gabite does suffer from having poor matchups into other NFE staples like Dunsparce, which can threaten Gabite with paralysis and coverage, and Piloswine, which can revenge kill Gabite with Ice Shard after minor chip damage.
Gabite.comments:
Other Options

Scale Shot can be used to provide a Speed boost, helping outpace Frogadier and Girafarig, though it does mean Gabite is much less threatening offensively, as it relies on the multi-hit nature of the move. Similarly, Gabite can opt for a fully offensive set, using a Choice Scarf to outspeed the aforementioned Pokemon without needing to rely on Scale Shot and coverage moves like Iron Head to hit Fairy-types harder, like Clefairy.

Checks and Counters

Faster Wallbreakers: Gabite is slower than notable revenge killers like Drakloak and Frogadier, both of which can threaten an OHKO with Draco Meteor and Ice Beam, respectively.

Piloswine: Piloswine's Ice Shard threatens an OHKO after Gabite takes minor chip damage.

Dunsparce: Dunsparce is quite difficult for Gabite to break through and can use Ice Beam to threaten an OHKO.

Wartortle: Wartortle can be problematic for Gabite, as it can use the threat of Ice Beam to get a free Shell Smash opportunity.

Swords Dance.description:
Gabite is a solid choice as an offensive setup option that also offers excellent utility in Stealth Rock and its Ground typing, which helps against notable entry hazard setters like Koffing and Tinkatuff. Substitute can be used to block status attempts from slower foes like Body Slam Dunsparce and Will-O-Wisp Koffing, allowing Gabite to use Swords Dance more freely; alternatively, Gabite can use Stealth Rock to free up a moveslot for teammates like Dunsparce and Tinkatuff. The given EV spread maximizes its damage output, with Adamant granting more immediate wallbreaking power at the expense of being slower than Monferno and Thwackey.

Gabite is a fine addition to many team structures, notably finding a role on balance and bulky offense teams as an offensive setup sweeper and wallbreaker. While Gabite can use its Ground typing to find setup opportunities against common foes like Koffing, Monferno, and Tinkatuff, it struggles with capitalizing on its boosts with the abundance of threats that can OHKO it, like Drakloak, Frogadier, and Piloswine. Teammates like Tinkatuff can help handle these threats by providing Knock Off support while sponging attacks from Drakloak and Frogadier. Quaxwell can also help handle them by providing slow pivots with Flip Turn, entry hazard removal with Rapid Spin, and it can take hits from Frogadier. Drakloak makes an excellent partner too, as it can threaten Will-O-Wisp on Piloswine to limit the damage output of Ice Shard while acting as a spinblocker against opposing Quaxwell. Ivysaur, Monferno, and Pignite are fine teammates for Gabite as well, offering Knock Off support to help remove Eviolite from physical walls, like opposing Ivysaur and Vullaby, to make wallbreaking easier for Gabite. Paralysis spreaders like Dunsparce, Drakloak, and Tinkatuff can enable Gabite offensively, allowing it to use Substitute to set up against paralyzed foes a bit more safely. Frogadier, as a partner to Stealth Rock Gabite, can create powerful hazard-stacking cores with Drakloak as the spinblocker. Girafarig is a great teammate to help Gabite get through Drakloak, providing a special wallbreaker to go with Gabite's physical wallbreaking. Raboot can help Gabite set up by providing safe entry points against common switch-ins like Koffing.

Defensive.description:
Defensive Gabite is an annoyance for physical attackers like Monferno and Quaxwell, punishing their attempts to pivot with its Rough Skin while capably setting up Stealth Rock for its team; Quaxwell can, however, use Ice-type coverage to hit Gabite. Dragon Tail gives Gabite great utility, as it can phaze setup threats, like Thwackey and Duosion, while also providing a way to rack up chip damage against common switch-ins like Dunsparce and Piloswine. Rest is Gabite's only form of recovery and can help accrue more Rough Skin and entry hazard chip damage throughout a game as well as remove pesky burns and poisons it may acquire from Koffing. A fully defensive EV spread ensures Gabite can sponge hits from the strongest physical attackers in the tier, like Monferno, Pignite, and Thwackey.

Spikes setters like Frogadier, and the more niche Quilladin, pair well with defensive Gabite, using the Stealth Rock it sets in conjunction with Dragon Tail to capitalize on the entry hazard stacking nature of these cores. Koffing can also function well with Gabite on hazard-stacking cores, using its potent Toxic Spikes to spread poison efficiently as, Gabite can deter opposing Koffing from coming onto the field to clear them. Ghost-type partners like Drakloak and Dusclops can similarly maintain these hazards by acting as spinblockers against Quaxwell. Dunsparce appreciates Gabite as a teammate, which can free up its moveslots, allowing it to run either Calm Mind or Coil sets more effectively; Dunsparce deals with threats like Drakloak and Piloswine in return. Similarly, Piloswine is a powerhouse that can capitalize on its wallbreaking proficiency with the support of Gabite, using Choice Band sets to great effect with the support of hazard chip that is accrued. While Gabite can use Rest to remove status from itself, it appreciates teammates that can more comfortably absorb Will-O-Wisp from Koffing, like Monferno and Pignite. These two also provide Gabite with Knock Off support, removing Eviolite to wear foes down even more quickly. Wallbreakers and cleaners like Girafarig, Wartortle, and Fraxure pair well with Gabite, as they can use the chip damage it accrues to enable their late-game cleaning, breaking past checks such as Dunsparce and Tinkatuff. Frogadier and Piloswine are enormous threats to Gabite, using their powerful Ice-type attacks to threaten an OHKO on it; Quaxwell is a valuable teammate to both sponge these attacks and remove hazards from the field for Gabite and its teammates. Similarly, Drakloak and Frogadier can threaten Gabite out with ease, making Ivysaur and Servine valuable teammates to take their attacks while also providing Knock Off support.

Servine.overview: Servine is a potent utility machine, capable of spreading paralysis consistently with its Glare and providing Knock Off support to remove the pesky Eviolite from would-be checks like Hisuian Sliggoo and Ivysaur. Contrary is a dangerous ability when used in conjunction with STAB Leaf Storm, allowing even defensive Servine sets to become difficult to wall after one or two boosts. With reliable recovery in Synthesis to complement great utility moves like Leech Seed and Taunt, Servine can be quite disruptive and difficult to take down with its passable natural bulk. It does, however, suffer from a weakness to common threats like Poison-types such as Ivysaur and Koffing, which can sponge its attacks comfortably, and Steel-types like Hisuian Sliggoo and Varoom, which can also take Servine on with ease. Strong Fire-types such as Monferno and Pignite can threaten Servine out consistently, allowing them to use their powerful STAB attacks and Knock Off to great effect.
Servine.comments:
Other Options

Choice Scarf Servine can be an effective speed control option, using its Leaf Storm in conjunction with Contrary to snowball quickly, as it outpaces foes like Frogadier and Drakloak. Leech Seed sets can be quite disruptive, with Substitute enabling this further by using Servine's comfortable Speed tier. Servine can use Light Screen and Reflect alongside Light Clay to enable offensive teammates, granting teammates like Dragon Dance Fraxure and Shell Smash Wartortle much easier opportunities to sweep, though this set is outclassed by screen setters like Morgrem and Drakloak, owing to their access to Prankster and higher Speed, respectively.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Monferno, Pignite, and Raboot can also use their powerful Fire-type STAB attacks to break through Servine, with the former two also getting access to Knock Off to be disruptive in general. Monferno and Raboot also have access to U-turn, which can allow teammates safe entry points to preserve momentum.

Poison-types: Ivysaur can comfortably stomach all of Servine's attacks and threaten it back with STAB Sludge Bomb or use Knock Off to disrupt foes. Koffing can similarly wall Servine with its Neutralizing Gas to cause stat drops with Contrary while threatening to spread Toxic Spikes; Levitate Koffing will struggle a bit more, though. Weepinbell is a niche pick but can use Servine as setup fodder, getting a safe Swords Dance to become a dangerous setup sweeper.

Steel-types: While Tinkatuff can't do much damage to Servine, it can effectively wall it and bother it with Knock Off and Thunder Wave. Hisuian Sliggoo can't risk using Acid Spray against Servine but can still threaten it with Ice Beam and Sludge Bomb. Varoom is an annoyance for Servine especially, with its 4x resistance to its STAB attacks allowing it to use Servine as setup fodder or disrupt foes with Toxic Spikes and Parting Shot.

Faster Wallbreakers: Faster wallbreakers like Girafarig and Frogadier can threaten high damage against Servine. Girafarig even has access to Sap Sipper, preventing Servine from getting boosts against it. Priority attacks from Pokemon like Choice Band Fraxure and Piloswine can also threaten to take down Servine after it takes chip damage or loses its Eviolite.

Defensive.description:
Servine is an efficient Knock Off user and offensive setup sweeper, using its powerful STAB Leaf Storm in conjunction with Contrary to rack up boosts while dishing out damage. Glare is a powerful tool to spread paralysis on even Ground-types that would normally sponge Nuzzle and Thunder Wave attempts, such as Gabite and Piloswine. Alternatively, Giga Drain can be used to capitalize on the boosts provided by Leaf Storm, becoming quite powerful itself and effective in preserving Leaf Storm PP. Tera Blast can hit Grass- and Poison-types like Ivysaur and Koffing. Maximum HP investment is used to provide Servine with some general bulk, helping it avoid an OHKO from Monferno and Piloswine and a 2HKO from foes like Choice Specs Drakloak and Gabite, while maximum Speed investment ensures it outspeeds Pokemon like Gabite, Ivysaur, and Monferno, which can allow a boosted Servine with Tera Blast to break through them after enough chip damage instead of being forced out.

Servine uses its utility as a Knock Off user and paralysis spreader effectively on balance and bulky offense teams, providing Eviolite removal to open up teammates like Monferno and Piloswine to clean late-game. Entry hazard support from teammates like Frogadier, Piloswine, and Tinkatuff is appreciated to wear down foes like Pignite and Raboot. Drakloak is an excellent partner for Servine, using the paralysis it spreads to boost its Hex damage. Offensive setup options like Swords Dance Gabite and Shell Smash Wartortle also appreciate the paralysis spreading Servine provides, using paralyzed foes like Dunsparce as setup opportunites. Quaxwell and Mareanie are valuable defensive teammates that can switch into Servine checks, like Monferno, Pignite, and Raboot, with Quaxwell providing hazard removal as well. Koffing can also help check these powerful Fire-types while providing Toxic Spikes support. Poison- and Steel-types like Koffing, Ivysaur, Hisuian Sliggoo, and Pawniard are dangerous Servine checks, which makes Ground-types like Gabite and Piloswine valuable for breaking through them. Sap Sipper Girafarig is capable of walling Servine with ease, using it as potential setup fodder on Nasty Plot sets, making teammates like Hisuian Sliggoo and Pawniard valuable to keep it in check.

Pignite.overview: Pignite is a powerful wallbreaker in the NFE metagame, using its powerful Fire- and Fighting-type STAB attacks to break through teams while having exceptional coverage in Knock Off and High Horsepower. Pignite is no slouch defensively either, with great natural bulk that makes it capable of trading blows with powerful foes like Monferno, Raboot, and Fraxure as needed. On top of this, it has access to Bulk Up which can make it even more imposing. While Pignite is a robust option for teams, it isn't without flaws; though it can usually sponge an attack or two from opposing wallbreakers, it can struggle to hit at times because of how slow it is. Monferno is a similar wallbreaker to Pignite that trades a little bit of power for more utility in U-turn, Slack Off, and Stealth Rock, which makes it slightly more favorable for some team compositions. Faster wallbreakers like Frogadier, Gabite, and Wartortle can all give Pignite problems, with the latter two capable of using it as setup fodder. To circumvent this, Pignite can use Sucker Punch to inflict damage before being KOed or even take down an unsuspecting revenge killer like Frogadier or Girafarig.
Pignite.comments:
Other Options

Bulk Up furthers Pignite's offensive and defensive capabilities and works well in conjunction with Sucker Punch to secure potential KOs against faster foes like Frogadier and Girafarig. Drain Punch is a weaker STAB attack than Close Combat but offers healing and doesn't lower its defenses. Choice Band sets rely more on prediction but can offer tremendous power, making Pignite much harder to wall.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Quaxwell is capable of sponging Pignite's attacks with ease while recovering any damage with Roost. Frogadier and Wartortle are faster wallbreakers that can threaten to revenge kill Pignite. Mareanie tanks most attacks thrown its way as well, easily recovering the damage with Regenerator.

Faster Wallbreakers: Given how slow Pignite is, nearly every wallbreaker in the tier can revenge kill it with ease once it has been chipped a bit. Notable examples include Gabite and Girafarig, though Girafarig has to look out for Sucker Punch. Fraxure can sponge an attack and use Pignite as setup fodder, as can Monferno though to a lesser extent.

All-Out Attacker.description:
Pignite is an effective wallbreaker, as its excellent Fire / Fighting typing can hit much of the metagame for large damage. Knock Off removes Eviolites to make wallbreaking easier for itself and teammates while also hitting Ghost- and Psychic-types like Drakloak and Girafarig hard. High Horsepower can be used to nail Fire- and Poison-types like Monferno, Koffing, Mareanie, and opposing Pignite; Sucker Punch is an alternative that helps circumvent its lower Speed to hit faster wallbreakers like Frogadier and Girafarig first. An Adamant nature allows Pignite to maximize its damage output while still outpacing foes like Piloswine and bulky Tinkatuff. Blaze can boost the power of Flare Blitz to the point of achieving notable damage rolls, including a 2HKO on Clefairy and Koffing, the latter after Stealth Rock.

Pignite is a natural fit on balance and bulky offense teams that need a powerful wallbreaker and additional Knock Off support. Faster wallbreakers like Frogadier and Girafarig can benefit from having Pignite remove Eviolites and wear teams down mid-game, allowing them to more effectively clean late-game. Entry hazard support from teammates like Gabite, Tinkatuff, and the aforementioned Frogadier can go a long way in chipping down the opposition, making would-be checks to Pignite like Mareanie and Quaxwell less capable of walling it over the course of a game. Drakloak can help spinblock against Quaxwell to ensure the hazards on the foes' side stay active, along with spreading status via Thunder Wave and Will-O-Wisp to help Pignite in its efforts to wallbreak. Frogadier and Wartortle are especially threatening foes for Pignite, so teammates that can keep them in check, such as Dunsparce and Tinkatuff, are vital. Specially defensive Clefairy can also wall these threats while providing Stealth Rock and Knock Off support. Quaxwell pairs well with Pignite, tanking Ground- and Water-type attacks thrown its way from the likes of Piloswine and Frogadier while providing hazard removal to keep it healthy. Thwackey checks the Water-types that threaten Pignite, such as Frogadier and Quaxwell, while using U-turn to provide safe entry points against foes like Ivysaur and Koffing that may try to check Thwackey. The Grassy Terrain provided by Thwackey also lowers the damage of Piloswine's Earthquake, allowing Pignite to more comfortably take it on if needed.

Fraxure.overview: Fraxure is an excellent wallbreaker and setup sweeper, possessing one of NFE's highest Attack stats and an offensive typing that's narrowly resisted. Access to Scale Shot enables it to bypass its low Speed and outspeed revenge killers like Frogadier and Girafarig, and its defensive typing allows it to set up on staples like Quaxwell and Thwackey. Choice Band sets are extremely threatening for their immediate power and access to First Impression, while Swords Dance sets terrify structures with their immense power after setup and Scale Shot to bypass Fraxure's mediocre Speed and ability to threaten revenge killers. However, Fraxure is held back by its low Speed and bulk; if it cannot use First Impression, much of the metagame can easily outspeed it, and even after a boost, Choice Scarf users like Frogadier and Monferno can easily revenge kill it. Fraxure's typing is a double-edged sword: while it is fantastic offensively and can let Fraxure set up against weaker walls, it also leaves Fraxure very vulnerable against metagame staples like Piloswine and Wartortle.
Fraxure.comments:
Other Options

Poison Jab can be used over Scale Shot to target Clefairy and the uncommon Morgrem while potentially poisoning bulky threats like Piloswine and Dunsparce, though the low poison chance combined with the move's narrower coverage makes it difficult to fit over another attack. Loaded Dice on Swords Dance sets can be used to buff Scale Shot's power, though this gives up some of Fraxure's already mediocre bulk. Dragon Dance can be an alternative way of setting up, though Scale Shot's immediate damage output makes Swords Dance the preferred option.

Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Tinkatuff, Clefairy, and the uncommon Morgrem are some of Fraxure's biggest threats; barring the rare Poison Jab, they can switch into Fraxure relatively easily and threaten it with either Thunder Wave or STAB attacks. Tinkatuff can even run Air Balloon to completely wall Fraxure barring First Impression.

Physical Walls: Physical walls like Koffing, Dunsparce, and Naclstack can comfortably stomach even a boosted Fraxure, threaten it with status, and heal off the damage with their recovery moves, with the latter two even using it as setup fodder. Koffing and Mareanie can set up Toxic Spikes to cut into Fraxure's sweeping potential, while Dunsparce can threaten it out with Ice Beam or set up Coil against it.

Faster Pokemon: Without First Impression, Fraxure's mediocre Speed leaves it vulnerable to most faster Pokemon, with threats like Girafarig, Frogadier, Drakloak, and Raboot easily able to pick it off with some prior damage.

Piloswine: Piloswine has good odds of surviving a +2 Outrage after Stealth Rock and can retaliate with its STAB moves, picking it off with Ice Shard after some chip damage or Defense drops from Scale Shot.

Residual Damage and Status: Fraxure is vulnerable to all entry hazards, and its sweeping potential can be dashed through burn or paralysis. Examples of common paralysis-spreading users include Hattrem, Servine, and Dunsparce, while Koffing and Drakloak can burn it.

Setup Sweeper.description:
With a Jolly nature and after a Swords Dance boost, Outrage is able to OHKO threats like Pignite and, with Stealth Rock, Wartortle. It also 2HKOes defensive staples like Quaxwell and Hattrem. Scale Shot can avoid Outrage's trapping effects and is used to finish off weakened foes or capitalize on Pokemon that can potentially switch out against it, like Quaxwell and Ivysaur. Stomping Tantrum provides key coverage against Tinkatuff and Pawniard while still letting Fraxure hit Fire-types like Pignite and Monferno hard without locking into Outrage. While a Jolly nature is helpful to outspeed Glimmet and Hakamo-o, an Adamant nature strengthens Fraxure's attacks and has improved odds of OHKOing threats like Piloswine with Outrage after a Swords Dance boost.

Fairy-types like Tinkatuff and Clefairy are some of Fraxure's biggest threats, being immune to Fraxure's STAB moves and having ways to work around its coverage. Pokemon like Piloswine and Koffing are excellent partners, with both providing entry hazards and absorbing paralysis and the latter even providing Toxic Spikes and Will-O-Wisp support to wear down foes. Paralysis spreaders like Tinkatuff and Hattrem are similarly good partners, slowing down faster foes like Frogadier and Girafarig that would otherwise easily revenge kill Fraxure. Tinkatuff also provides Knock Off support, and Hattrem can use Healing Wish to give Fraxure a second chance at sweeping. Other wallbreakers and cleaners, like Thwackey and Raboot, are also helpful in working together with Fraxure to more easily break down the opposition. Popular revenge killers like Frogadier, Piloswine, and Drakloak can threaten Fraxure out without too much trouble, so teammates like Clefairy, Quaxwell and Dunsparce can provide defensive backbones against these threats.

Choice Band.description:
Fraxure is one of the best wallbreakers and revenge killers in the metagame owing to its colossal Attack and amazing movepool. First Impression is its primary revenge killing tool, being able to pick off several top-tier threats such as Girafarig, Thwackey, and Frogadier. Dragon Claw, unlike Outrage, doesn't lock Fraxure in and helps it avoid being crippled by Fairy-types like Clefairy and Tinkatuff. Stomping Tantrum hits Tinkatuff, 2HKOes Koffing, and OHKOes Pawniard after Stealth Rock damage. An Adamant nature maximizes Fraxure's offensive potential, letting it hit thresholds like always 2HKOing Quaxwell with Outrage and maximum Defense Tinkatuff with Stomping Tantrum.

Fraxure fits on bulky offense and balance teams as a dedicated physical wallbreaker and anti-offense revenge killer. It works best when paired with pivots and entry hazard setters, as they provide it with entry opportunities and facilitate its wallbreaking. Frogadier excels in both roles, making it a wonderful partner. Quaxwell, Raboot, and Thwackey provide pivoting support and handle Piloswine, one of the best checks to Fraxure; moreover, Quaxwell provides Rapid Spin support, ensuring Fraxure stays for long in the game. Fraxure can't afford to take Knock Off because it loses too much power; Tinkatuff helps by acting as a Knock Off absorber and also provides Stealth Rock and Knock Off support. Other hazard-setting teammates include Piloswine and Koffing. Piloswine can also act as a Tinkatuff switch-in in case Fraxure is Choice-locked into a move other than Stomping Tantrum. Fraxure is vulnerable to paralysis spreaders like Hattrem and Clefairy, which can cut into its offensive prowess. Thus, paralysis absorbers like Gabite and Koffing are great teammates. Special wallbreakers work excellently with Fraxure, ripping apart defensive cores with ease. Choice Specs Drakloak, Hisuian Sliggoo, and aforementioned Girafarig are all suited for the job. Fraxure appreciates Knock Off support a lot because Eviolite removal makes it even deadlier in its job. Thus, Pokemon like Monferno, Pignite, Vullaby as well as the previously mentioned Thwackey pair amazingly with it, with Vullaby even providing Defog support. Fraxure often gets Choice-locked in the wrong move, so having a solid defensive core backing it up is of utmost importance, especially on balance teams. Defensive options to pair Fraxure with include Pokemon like Ivysaur, Drakloak, and the aforementioned Quaxwell and Koffing.

Frogadier.overview: Frogadier stands out as a stellar offensive pivot, revenge killer, and, if it's running Heavy-Duty Boots, the best Spikes setter of the metagame thanks to its versatile movepool and great Speed tier. These traits cement Frogadier as a centerpiece in the metagame's most dominant structures, particularly entry hazard-stacking teams with Spikes. Choice Specs Frogadier's offensive potential is matched by few, and the Choice Scarf variant is the fastest Pokemon in the metagame, making it one of the most effective revenge killers. However, it's limited by Thwackey and Water-types, though the latter can be hindered by Choice item variants' Switcheroo.
Frogadier.comments:
Other Options

Hydro Pump can be used over Surf as a stronger but less accurate option; Hydro Pump 2HKOes Eviolite Girafarig after Stealth Rock, while Surf fails to accomplish this. Gunk Shot over Ice Beam with a Naive nature is an alternative, transforming Frogadier's Grass weakness into a resistance and allowing it to potentially turn the tables on foes like Thwackey. Grass Knot is also a niche option, 2HKOing Quaxwell and Wartortle that have lost their Eviolite after minor chip damage, usually from entry hazards; it also removes Frogadier's Grassy Glide weakness.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Quaxwell and Wartortle can shrug off its moves and use Rapid Spin to clear Spikes. Wartortle, however, has a limit to how long it can keep Frogadier at bay because it lacks a good recovery move. Quaxwell is comparatively better at answering Frogadier long-term thanks to Roost giving it great longevity. Niche Water-types such as Mareanie, Dewott, and Seadra are also decent answers to Frogadier. However, Choice item Frogadier can hinder all these Water-types with Switcheroo.

Grass-types: Thwackey's Grassy Glide is a nightmare for Frogadier. Other Grass-types like Ivysaur and Servine can also check it. These Grass-types, however, do fear switching into Frogadier's Ice Beam.

Special Walls: Frogadier fails to deal significant damage to Pokemon like Dunsparce, Duosion, Clefairy, and Tinkatuff, but all of these can threaten it in return. However, it is worth noting that Tinkatuff fails to check Frogadier long-term.

Dragon-types: Hisuian Sliggoo, Choice Specs Drakloak, and First Impression Fraxure can revenge kill Frogadier.

Spikes Pivot.description:
Spikes lets Frogadier heavily pressure the opposing team while also making it immune to Thunder Wave due to Protean. Ice Beam hits Grass- and Dragon-types like Thwackey, Ivysaur, Fraxure, and Drakloak and removes its Grass weakness, allowing it to always survive Eviolite Thwackey's Grassy Glide. U-turn allows it to escape problematic matchups, such as Quaxwell and Wartortle, and generate momentum by bringing its teammates in on advantageous matchups.

Frogadier fits on offense and balance teams focused on setting entry hazards. Ghost-types are nearly mandatory teammates for Frogadier, providing spinblocking support to ensure Spikes stay up on the field in a metagame where Rapid Spin is the primary hazard removal method. Drakloak is a good consideration due to its good typing, Speed tier, and movepool. Pawniard is also a decent partner for Frogadier, punishing Defog attempts from Vullaby with Defiant—even though Defog is relatively uncommon—and using the Attack boost to potentially clean or dent the opposing team. Frogadier pairs excellently with other hazard setters like Tinkatuff, Piloswine, Gabite, and Koffing, supporting it in relentlessly pressuring the opposing team with hazards and other utility or damage-dealing moves. Tinkatuff and Koffing also help Frogadier in dealing with Grass-types, most notably Thwackey, which can easily revenge kill Frogadier with Grassy Glide. Strong Pokemon such as Thwackey, Pikachu, Raboot, Pignite, and Girafarig heavily appreciate Frogadier's Spikes support, which enables them to wallbreak or clean with ease. Thwackey assists Frogadier by dealing with threats like Quaxwell and Wartortle, while Frogadier threatens Fire-types like Raboot, Monferno, and Pignite for Thwackey. Pikachu is a good partner for similar reasons, and it appreciates Frogadier threatening Ground-types such as Piloswine and Gabite. Setup variants of Dunsparce and Duosion are also terrific teammates, being excellent wincons through their bulk, helpful abilities, and reliable recovery. Defensive teammates for Frogadier include Pokemon like Quaxwell and Ivysaur. Quaxwell provides the much-needed Rapid Spin support, ensuring Frogadier's team is unaffected by hazards while the opposing team writhes in agony due to them. Ivysaur fends off pesky Grass- and Water-types for Frogadier.

Choice Specs.description:
Choice Specs Frogadier is an extremely threatening wallbreaker that has few long-term checks. Surf and Protean-boosted Ice Beam have few Pokemon that resist both moves, and U-turn allows Frogadier to gain momentum on anything it can't blow past immediately. Spikes is another way to punish Frogadier's defensive checks like Quaxwell and Hisuian Sliggoo by wearing them down with indirect damage. Hydro Pump is worthy of strong consideration with Choice Specs, as it OHKOes Piloswine, which can otherwise OHKO Frogadier back. Switcheroo is a great disruptive tool against both defensive staples like Tinkatuff and Quaxwell and setup sweepers like Dunsparce.

While not limited to hyper offense, Choice Specs Frogadier prefers to be on faster teams that can take advantage of its early wallbreaking power. Thwackey is an excellent offensive partner to pivot to, as it can immediately threaten Quaxwell, Frogadier's most common switch-in. Late-game setup sweepers like Girafarig and Duosion can take advantage of the early-game progress that Frogadier makes against defensive cores. If running Spikes, then a Ghost-type like Drakloak is essential to block Rapid Spin. Piloswine and Tinkatuff can both serve as checks to Hisuian Sliggoo while also being capable of setting Stealth Rock to chip at Frogadier's checks. Lastly, a Grassy Glide switch-in like Girafarig or Ivysaur is important, as Thwackey is a natural revenge killer for Frogadier.

Choice Scarf.description:
With a Choice Scarf, Frogadier becomes the fastest Pokemon in the tier and can act as an excellent pivot, revenge killer, and late-game cleaner. Surf threatens Choice Scarf Monferno and Trailblaze Pignite, while Ice Beam hits Drakloak and Scale Shot-boosted Gabite. U-turn is critically important to pivot on defensive answers to Frogadier like Quaxwell and Tinkatuff. Switcheroo + Choice Scarf can cripple setup sweepers like Wartortle, Duosion, and Girafarig and a few key defensive pieces like Quaxwell and Clefairy. Spikes supports Frogadier's team and is a more valuable way to punish its checks in longer games.

Choice Scarf Frogadier can easily slot into a variety of team structures. Faster builds appreciate its revenge killing capabilities, but slower, more defensively oriented structures can still strongly take advantage of the utility Switcheroo and Spikes give and the potential late-game wincon Frogadier provides. Frogadier synergizes very well with Stealth Rock setters like Piloswine and Tinkatuff, as Frogadier can stop their common offensive checks like Monferno and Gabite. Frogadier also naturally forces a lot of switches, which helps rack up entry hazard damage. Fire-type offensive pivots like Raboot and Monferno can both maintain offensive momentum with U-turn while threatening walls like Dunsparce and Tinkatuff. They also offensively check Thwackey, which is a natural predator to Frogadier thanks to Grassy Glide. Grass-types like Thwackey and offensive Ivysaur both function as strong wallbreakers that punish Quaxwell and Clefairy for switching in and can easily be brought in with U-turn. Ivysaur also functions as a solid defensive check to opposing Thwackey. Despite sharing the same type, Quaxwell is a great teammate, as hazard removal makes Frogadier's pivot-centric playstyle less taxing, and, after a Flip Turn, Frogadier can punish the Ghost-types that Quaxwell invites in like Drakloak with Switcheroo or Ice Beam. If running Spikes, a spinblocking Ghost-type is nearly essential to keep it up.

Thwackey.overview: Thwackey is one of NFE's top wallbreakers, pivots, and cleaners, and it's a staple for offensive teams. Whether it runs Choice Band to immediately empower its moves or Swords Dance to make it even scarier to switch into, its threatening Grassy Terrain-powered attacks like the powerful Wood Hammer and priority move in Grassy Glide can decimate teams without a Grass-resistant Pokemon, and even Grass-resistant Pokemon do not appreciate its utility in Knock Off and U-turn. Unlike most wallbreakers, Thwackey's Grassy Glide also enables it to pick off faster wallbreakers like Frogadier and Pikachu, and its Grassy Surge ability also provides valuable healing for offensive and defensive Pokemon that need recovery, like Pignite and Tinkatuff. However, Thwackey can struggle to bypass Grass-resistant checks like Tinkatuff and Ivysaur due to relying on its utility moves for coverage. Outside of Grassy Terrain, its merely good Speed leaves it vulnerable to getting picked off by faster attackers like Frogadier and Drakloak.
Thwackey.comments:
Other Options

A Grassy Seed + Acrobatics set gives Thwackey extra coverage against Grass-types like Servine, Ivysaur, and opposing Thwackey without needing to pivot, though Grassy Seed's one-time nature and needing to give up U-turn or Swords Dance makes this set more difficult to fit.

Checks and Counters

Poison-types: Poison-types like Koffing, Ivysaur, and Varoom give Thwackey immense trouble by resisting its STAB moves and can heavily threaten it out with status and their own STAB moves in return.

Fire-types: Monferno, Raboot, and the uncommon Fletchinder can threaten immense damage on Thwackey with their STAB moves, though Raboot has a small chance of getting OHKOed by a boosted Wood Hammer, and Fletchinder hates stomaching Knock Off. While Pignite is slower and lacks U-turn, its bulk makes up for it and remains similarly threatening.

Steel-types: Steel-types like Hisuian Sliggoo and Tinkatuff resist its STAB moves and retaliate with powerful STAB moves or utility with Thunder Wave and Knock Off, respectively.
